title: ID this unknown flinty brand font
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331025607im_/http:/typophile.com/files/QQ%E6%88%AA%E5%9B%BE%E6%9C%AA%E5%91%BD%E5%90%8D_5495.jpg)
  
Your courtesy reply will be appreciated.
author: ryanshieh

comments.content: I don't know what it is, but I would advise you not to put (x) in the title of your post. The admin who watches the Type ID Board adds that when a typeface has been identified. By including it, you are, in effect, telling everyone to ignore your question because it appears that it's already been answered.

As the one who made the post you can edit the title, and Mark's advice is good.

This 'techno' style is probably a freebie you can find at Dafont under techno\>scifi category. For some reason, techno fonts are favorites of amateur designers.

- Mike Yanega
I'm realy sorry about the title,and I have edited it. Thanks you for your advises. Amateur designers are always everywhere,more amateur,more professional.

Far from cigar but you could start using [Bitsumishi](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331025607/http:/www.dafont.com/bitsumishi.font) (lower and uppercases) (or [Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331025607/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/cheapprofonts/bitsumishi-pro/regular/) includes alternate /R/ and /B/)... Stretching, adding outline stroke and reacreating /R/ using /B/ for instance...
